14/ And get objective opinions not just recent fundings. It early days it’s Saul Goodman. Find out how the season ends
13/ My advice: seek advice from founders who have hit the backside of leaderless rounds over past 5 years
12/ The market is the market so leaderless rounds will continue for some time. As founders just consider long-term consequences
11/ Rank-and-file employees (99% of company) benefit from better governance at board level but aren’t aware of how this can impact them
10/ If you want examples of hard early days read Googled by Ken Auletta or history of Apple, Twitter.
9/ If always up & to the right leaderless rounds work. Things are never always up & to the right
8/ Convertible notes: kick-can-down-road on governance & reporting = less sunshine on decision making. Sunshine is harder but better results
7/ Oversight is why democracy trumps autocracy in the long run
6/ Oversight helped build management teams, figure out monetization & raise capital. Oversight a pain. But interactions drive performance
5/ Industry’s best companies benefitted from strong oversight in early years: Google, Facebook, Twitter.
4/ Leaderless rounds often no professional governance, reporting & decision-making frameworks. Hurts company, employees & investors
3/ False illusion that it’s in founder or employee interests. Strong investor = commitment, neck-on-line, owns good times & bad
2/ Leaderless round trend led by rise of angels, explosion of seed funds & crowd funding. Easy short-term money, not always good long-term
